status_message:
"In December I was diagnosed with Breast Cancer. On 1/27/16 I had a double mastectomy. The breast cancer spread to my lymph nodes on the right side and I was at stage three. I started Chemotherapy on 2/22/16 and finished today 6/13/16. It wasn't easy, but my family and friends helped me through it. Next is Surgery on 7/6/16 to take out the expanders and put in the implants. Then a month after surgery I will start Radiation Mon-Fri for six weeks. After all this, I will pray that I'm healthy! The only advice that I could give others is to stay positive, smile, laugh and love. Enjoy the little things in life and don't take anything for granted. If you love someone, tell them! ❤️"

Denise, congrats on your last day of chemo!!! Thank you for sharing your story and picture with us :)

status_message:
"IT CAME! WE FOUGHT! I'M WINNING!! 💁🏼 
Im DONE I've KNOCKED OUT 👊🏼👊🏼 all 16 rounds (20 weeks) of gnarly chemo cocktails!! IT WAS TOUGH BUT I WAS TOUGHER!! Many doctors appts, too many miles back/forth to Charlotte to even count, a tattoo, short hair, no hair, no eyebrows, no eyelashes, no shaving legs, being tired tired tired, 36 foster dogs & 2 foster failures(lol) and tremendous support from family and friends(old & new) later and this chapter is OVER!! These lady's have taken excellent care of me and been awesome nurses, it's bittersweet that I'm leaving them. I have alot of living left to do and cancer is not taking that away from me. Next up is surgery then 6 weeks of radiation. #HitCancerInTheMouth 👊🏼
#KeepPounding 🔨#ThisLittleLightOfMineImGoingLetItShine 🌟#RefuseToSink ⚓️
#StayStrong 💪🏼
#IveGotSunshineInMyPocket ☀️
#KissCancerGoodbye 👄👋🏼 
#CancerSurvivor 🎀
#CanIGetMyNailsDoneNow 💅🏼 "

Daniell, congrats on your last day of chemo!!! You're a rockstar!!!! Thank you for sharing this photo and your story with us <3

status_message:
Thousands of dogs and cats, many of them stolen pets, are captured and transported over long distances under horrific conditions to Yulin, a city in China's Guangxi Autonomous Region. There, they're held in crowded cages without food or water until they are killed. 

Often, they are beaten and their throats are slit in front of other terrified animals. Most Chinese citizens reject this practice, and we're committed to supporting them in ending the festival in actuality.

Please sign our petition now to urge the Yulin authorities to intervene and end mass dog slaughter in the name of a festival.

SIGN HERE >>> http://po.st/KZcgwg

status_message:
"So honored and humbled to be here at the Relay for Life with the greatest team of caregivers anyone could ever have!
I'm very pleased to announce that I received over $1000 in donations for the American Cancer Society on behalf of my team, "Holly's Heroes" and have obtained the "Rising Star" level. The support and kindness that I have been showered with is INCREDIBLE!! 
You have all touched my heart beyond measure. I'm walking today to honor those who have passed through the awful storm of Cancer and are now enjoying their rainbows. I'm walking today to help hold the umbrella for those who are still enduring the storm, but most importantly I'm walking today to pay it forward so no more need to weather the storm at all. 💕"

Holly, you are amazing!!! Thank you for supporting breast cancer awareness and thank you for raising $1,000 in donations!

status_message:
"To all of our fb friends and family, i would like to start a prayer circle for my dear niece Christy. If u know her u know she battled breast cancer 2 years ago and was finally getting back to herself! She went to dr bcz she was having a bad migraine and they admitted her saying she has a tumor the size of a gulf ball in her head that is cancerous and it spread from her breast cancer and want to perform gamma surgery. I am not claiming that for her bcz i know the God we serve is the ultimate healer! We need your help to come in agreement with us that she will be healed and wont need the surgery! God we hand it over to you, you said by your stripes we are healed and if we ask we shall receive, if we knock the door will be opened and if we seek we shall find, so were coming in agreement that you will heal her completely from head to toe in Jesus name Amen!!"

MJ, thank you for sharing this message and photo with us. Everyone, please give Christy prayers and words of encouragement!
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
"I'm now a two-time breast cancer survivor. My first round was in 2012. I had the agressive, triple negative kind in my left breast. I underwent ATC chemo, lumpectomy and radiation and was pronounced as "in remission" in 2012. I was shocked when I was diagnosed with it again in October of 2015. Again, I took CT chemotherapy, surgery and radiation. Since this recurrence was within 3 years of the first, we're going to get agressive and start 3 rounds of CT chemotherapy next week. I love this site. I gain courage from all the survivors out there!"

Betsy, congrats on your last day of radiation!!! YOU'RE AMAZING! Thank you for sharing this photo with us :)
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
"This is my amazing mother. She was diagnosed in October of 2015 with stage 1 Invasive Ductual Carcinoma. We meet with her panel of doctors in November, by December she under went a mastectomy on her left breast. They took 6 lymph nodes and all 6 came back positive. She was estrogen positive and also the cancer had spread to her spine and to her bones and 3 parts in her back. She is now a stage 4. She started the "Red Devil" treatment a couple weeks later and ended with Taxol today on 5-23-2016. She still has 30 rounds of Radiation still ahead, but I needed to give a shout out to her for being so strong and never giving up! This hit our family hard and very fast. But were conquering this nasty disease and this will not knock us down. My mother was a struggling single mom, and I had the best childhood growing up. My mother has always been there for no matter and I can't tell u how grateful it feels that I get to be here for her. Mother you are my best friend and MY HERO!"

Lindsey, thank you for sharing this picture of your mother. Congrats to your mother!!! She is a hero to you and a true inspiration to many <3
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Today is my last day of chemo!! At age 33 I never imagined this day would come let alone be diagnosed with stage 2 breast cancer. No family history just pain in my chest. It felt like I pulled a muscle boxing. Docs found 3 tumors and 1 lymph node so we started with chemo first...4 rounds of A/C and 12 rounds of taxol in 8 infusions... done done done!! To celebrate today we also did a ballon release...one for each day of chemo. Gone are those balloons and my days of chemo infusions. Next stop double mastectomy next month."

Erin, congrats on your last day of chemo!!! YOU'RE AMAZING <3. Thank you for sharing your photo and message with us :)

status_message:
"Today is a day to celebrate. Today is my last day of chemo and I couldn't be happier. For most of you who know me, I'm not one to put my health issues out here on social media, but for this, I'll make an exception. Being diagnosed with breast cancer last year was probably the scariest/worst moment of my life. I never thought that a doctor would say that dreaded phrase "You have breast cancer". Needless to say, as much as it scared me, it also motivated me to fight. I wouldn't let this diagnosis define me and I went into survival mode by having immediate surgery and chemotherapy treatment.
There are a few things I've learned on this journey.
1. Getting Chemotherapy is not as scary as I thought it would be. If you could get past that annoying IV in your arm for a few hours, it's bearable.
2. Just because you're getting chemo, doesn't mean you have to lose your hair. I didn't. Thank God for Penguin Cold Caps and for my amazing husband who changed those caps every 30 minutes on treatment days. I don't know what I'd do without him.
3. Cancer treatment changes you, physically and mentally, but one thing to remember (I sometimes forget this too) is to be kind to yourself. These changes that are happening in your body are only temporary and you will get back to where you're comfortable again (for me it's yoga!🙏🏼) 
4. Laugh often. I've learned that laughter is really the best medicine and I've also learned that smiling, even when I didn't want to, always improved my day.

I want to thank all my family, friends, and coworkers for the support. I am so grateful for the hospital visits, meals cooked, cards, calls and texts. It was all so encouraging and motivated me to stay positive throughout treatment.

I would also like to thank the doctors and nurses at Memorial Sloan Kettering, Weill-Cornell, and Stamford Hospital for the incredible level of care they've given me. Because of them, I can proudly say that I am CANCER FREE!! Woohoo!!! #cancershmancer #stand⬆️2c"

Lisa, it is definitely a day to celebrate and we're so happy to be celebrating with you! Congrats on your last day of chemo!!!! :) Thank you for sharing <3
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: YES!!!
link_name: The Fight Against This Deadly Cancer Has A New Ally!

status_message:
"I was diagnosed November 3, 2015 with stage 2b invasive ductal carcinoma with no family history. I was scheduled to start chemotherapy right away. December 8, 2015 I started my first A/C round. I completed 4 rounds of A/C, then on to 12 rounds of Taxol. I was only sick one time during my 6 months of chemo. I kept a very positive attitude the entire time and had lots of loving and helpful friends and family that helped me and my children!! I completed my chemo on May 17, 2016 like a champ!! I kept a goal in my head and now that chemo is over, I can take a trip to see my eldest child graduate school!!! Then home to complete 2 surgeries and radiation!! I know I can do this for my family and myself!! I am a fighter and will never let cancer take me down!!! "

Stephanie, CONGRATS TO YOU!!! Thank you for sharing :)

status_message:
"On Dec 10, 2015 I found a lump on my breast. I had a diagnostic mamagram, a ultrasound and biopsy done.
On Dec 28, 2015 I was diagnosed with stage 2 breast cancer (triple negative )
On Dec 31,2015 I had a lumpectomy and lymph node removal.
In Feb I began Chemotherapy. 
Today is my last Chemo Treatment! 6 weeks of radiation to follow. 
I couldn't have done it without my family, friends and library co-workers. Thank you EAPL family for the beautiful sign💖

'Holding hands with you is like a promise that, if even for a brief moment or a few hours, we don't have to face the world alone.'"

Betty, congrats on your last day of chemo!!! :) :) :) Thank you for sharing your lovely photo and message with us <3

status_message:
"My last chemo today(4.25.16)

Diagnosed in September 4,2015. Never thought my life would take this path but it has. Double mastectomy with reconstruction and expanders on October 20, 2015 two days before my 44th birthday. I was told that day that it had spread to my lymph nodes so I would need chemo and radiation. I was so heartbroken and scared! I have now faced the surgery and 4 rounds of adriamycin and cytoxin followed by 12 rounds of taxol. I was so blessed with so much support and prayers. I believe each and every one of them helped because I may have been tired but never got sick! So today I put another chapter behind me...I have completed chemo! On to radiation! Bless everyone who fights this fight!"

Nikkie, congrats on your last day of chemo!!!! Thank you for sharing your message and story with us <3

"As I sit here on my last day of chemo. I was thinking about you. I have learned a lot the last 8 months. "I am not only a Breast Cancer Survivor, for 4 months now, but just finished preventive Chemo for Ovarian Cancer when they found a 2mm spot on my left Fallopian Tube in Pathology, after a double mastectomy and hysterectomy February 1st. status_message:
"Oct 13 2015 was diagnosed with stage 3 invasive lobular breast cancer had complete mastectomy on right breast with dorsal flap reconstruction immediately. Started chemo January 2016 just finished my last treatment. I have six weeks of radiation next. I had genetic testing during my chemo because of family history my father passed away from stomach cancer at age 38. I am CDH 1 positive. When I finish radiation I need another mastectomy on left side then a total gastrectomy to follow. Removal of the stomach is the only way to prevent stomach cancer. I am scared, but I am a single mom of two beautiful girls 19 and 18. They are my world and I will fight for them. It is not an easy road this monster tries to break me every day but I will not give up. When I can't fight I have an army of friends and family praying and fighting for me. Thank you for the love and support God Bless"

Christine, congrats on your las day of chemo!! Thank you for sharing <3
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
"The summer of 2010 was when my life changed, my Mom had been fighting her own cancer battle that was quickly coming to an end. I had spent the last two months of her life taking care of her, she lost her battle August 31, 2010. One week later, I was taking a bath and discovered a lump in my right breast. And the world wind begins.

I immediately made an appointment with my family doctor, who sent me in for a mammogram, she thought it was nothing, but scheduled it anyway. After the mammogram, I was told I had Invasive Ductal Carcanoma. Then approximately about 6 weeks later I was scheduled for a double mastectomy..."

Continue Reading Debbie's Story ► http://po.st/UfNsUg

status_message:
"It has been awhile since I posted!! I was diagnosed 8-30-2013. Had a double mastectomy 10-1-2013( great way to kickstart Breast Cancer Awareness), Then did chemo. I was engaged to be married 10-18-2014 but we postponed it a year for recovery and reconstructed surgery!
Breast Cancer is an awful diagnoses. I still lived my life to the fullest! My family and friends kept my spirits up and always made sure I was doing well! My fiancé but my husband now stayed by my side! He is the most loving, loyal, wonderful, man I could ever ask for!❤️
I just want you to know if your recently diagnosed, battling, and surviving! You will get through it! You will be stronger than ever! Embrace being bald! It's fun and people want mess with you being bald! 😂 
Here is a picture of me 2 weeks before surgery, the bald one is me on my last chemo 1-14-2014, my wedding 10-17-2015 and how I'm wearing my short hair!

Keep fighting ladies! Stay strong! God is with you all the way!! Not a day doesn't go by I think of my journey, your journey and not a day doesn't go by I think and pray for you all! 🙏🏻

God Bless you and Love to all!"

Brandi, thank you so much for your encourage words to all the survivors and fighters out there. You are amazing and you have an equally amazing husband <3. Thank you for sharing your picture and words with us :)

status_message:
"On October 30th I found out my lump was her2 and er positive! I'm only 32 just 2 years married with an 18 month baby girl! My life felt like it was ending!! I was terrified! After have a bilateral mastectomy and beginning stages of reconstruction, I started my chemo of htcp in January and today marked my last chemo!! I am nowhere being done! I have 4-6 weeks of radiation coming up and continued Herceptin for a year and then an ER blocker pill! These nurses are amazing and I can even explain my friends and family's support! God gives us what we can handle and helps us fight through it!! Prayers to all warriors out there!! Keep fighting!!"

Sarah, BIG CONGRATS to you!!! Thank you for sharing <3

status_message:
"Oct 13 2015 was diagnosed with stage 3 invasive lobular breast cancer had complete mastectomy on right breast with dorsal flap reconstruction immediately. Started chemo January 2016 just finished my last treatment. I have six weeks of radiation next. I had genetic testing during my chemo because of family history my father passed away from stomach cancer at age 38. I am CDH 1 positive. When I finish radiation I need another mastectomy on left side then a total gastrectomy to follow. Removal of the stomach is the only way to prevent stomach cancer. I am scared, but I am a single mom of two beautiful girls 19 and 18. They are my world and I will fight for them. It is not an easy road this monster tries to break me every day but I will not give up. When I can't fight I have an army of friends and family praying and fighting for me. Thank you for the love and support God Bless"

Christine, congrats on your last day of chemo!!! Thank you for sharing your story and photo with us :)

status_message:
"In 2010 my mother called me and said she had been diagnosed with breast cancer, that it was time for me to come home. At that time I lived in Nashville, Tn worked at Vanderbilt. A great job that I really did like and enjoy. 

So I prayed about it and God led me back to Kentucky. I got a job at a local hospital (not good pay) but, I was here for my mother I thought. Three months later I had a blood clot in my leg so I had surgery. 

They put in a stint, a week later another blood clot. Doctor said something is wrong so he did lab work, cat scan, and a ultrasound. The doctor came into the room and sat on the bed and said you have breast cancer..."

Continue Reading Beverly's Story ► http://po.st/Cr9h3L

status_message:
"In 2011 at 31, instead of enjoying time with husband and 5 kids, I was bone tired. Went to doctor, nothing was found. In September I started leaking blood from right breast. Went back to family doc, who sent me for mammogram/ultrasound. 

I went over to lab for that, and was treated like an idiot. Scans showed cysts, nothing else. I asked about bleeding and heard, Youre young, come back in year for recheck. I was cut off, told they know what theyre doing. 

I called family doctor to complain, he sent me in to surgeon to see about biopsies. Surgeon refused, said wasnt necessary since the cysts were benign..."

Continue Reading Sara's Story ► http://po.st/A1oUTq

One day me and one of my sons were riding in the car and i felt a lump under my right arm and I knew it didn't feel right, so I made a appointment to see the Doctor we scheduled the mammogram and that's when he noticed the lump in my right breast.

We did the biopsy and low and behold it was cancerous, I opted for the mastectomy because..."

status_message:
"A little over 7 years ago, a week before my 59th birthday, I happened to be home from work due to a bronchitis attack over the weekend. It was a Monday morning and I was on the couch resting. 

The phone rang, I answered, and was told that I need to have an ultrasound because my mammogram, a week prior, showed a lump on my right breast. I set up the appointment, hung up the phone, and felt the lump. I knew right then that it was cancer. Two days later I had the ultrasound. 

The tech said she was going to have a doctor come in to talk to me. The lady doctor who came in was very curt and matter-of-fact and said to me..."

Continue Reading Fran's Story ► http://po.st/V3pyc9

status_message:
"Taking control is what has gotten me through the toughest times. I agonized about losing my hair, so I shaved my head on the first day of chemo because I was not going to let cancer take it from me. 

I have never felt so liberated in my life! I felt like a rock star that day, and now feel more beautiful than I ever have. I got in a rut for about 2 months, so I decided it was time to take control of something again. 

I have been inspired by other survivors who have gone on to do great things with charities and helping others. I'm terrible about asking for money so I knew a charity was not in my future..."

status_message:
"I was 46 yrs old, in 2005, when I heard the phrase...."You have cancer". As a 25 yr Oncology RN, I was ANGRY! Had spent 25 yrs taking care of cancer pts... How can it be me??? It's not fair!! But it was me.

My mother had had breast cancer. I was so scared. I was in a horrible marriage, drinking to escape. Now that I had been handed a "death sentence", convinced I was going to die, and deserved to die, my drinking soared. 

No one wanted to be around me I had, what was supposed to be, a lumpectomy. My surgeon missed a "bleeder" and 24 hrs after being home, the remaining breast was hugely swollen with blood. Second surgery was immediate..."

status_message:
"My story begins September 2013 when I discovered a lump. I was 53 and I've always gone for my annual mammograms since age 40 and have no family history of breast cancer. 

Although I hadn't been doing regular self exams, I was not concerned thinking it was from the dog jumping on me and my annual mammogram was scheduled for just a few weeks later anyway. 

When the lump didn't go away, I saw my doctor and she prescribed a diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound. After those and a biopsy, I was diagnosed with aggressive stage 3a triple negative breast cancer on October 24, my Dad's birthday..."

status_message:
"On Tuesday July 23, 2013 I found my 5+cm lump above my left nipple after showering that morning, noticing the dimpling in the mirror while looking back at myself. I should've caught this in a self breast exam, it was THAT noticeable. 

I was diagnosed on August 8th and had my mastectomy on September 9th, removing my entire left breast and 6 lymph nodes, 1 which had cancer detected in it. I elected to have reconstruction done at the same time and I am still going through that process.

In October I started with my chemo treatments, having the "red devil" Adriamycin and Cytoxan, with the Neulasta shot (white blood cell rebuilder) the day after. I was supposed to have 4 of these treatments, but only made it through..."

"On Friday, November 13, 2015 I was diagnosed with Stage 2b triple-negative, invasive ductal carcinoma. I had been treating a rash on my breast, with cream, when I felt a lump. It was a shocking diagnosis because I was faithful to my check ups & mammograms. 
I just finished my 8th round of chemo on Wednesday, March 30, 2016!!! I will have a double mastectomy in May followed by 6 weeks of radiation."

Big congratulations to you, Danielle! Thank you for sharing this photo with us :)

status_message:
"In Feb 2013 my cat and best friend Rocky was diagnosed with high grade hepatic lymphoma. His oncologist gave a 30-60 day prognosis. We elected not to do chemo and he is now in month 7 and doing fabulous on his meds, you would never know he has cancer!! 

3 months later in May I had a routine mammogram come back showing 2 lumps. An immediate ultrasound showed 4 lumps. 

Biopsies came back with both Invasive Ductal Carcinoma and Invasive Lobular Carcinoma. I remember walking out of that hospital after the mammogram just feeling numb..."

Continue Reading Roberta's Story ► http://po.st/JbLI0k

"When I was diagnosed with Breast cancer a few years back, I reacted like most who receive a cancer diagnose; first thing came to mind was a "death sentence". 

However, I found out later that it was truly "an awakening" for me, even after being diagnosed with another (colon) cancer a few years later. 

I began questioning God, why would you do this to me? What had I done in life so bad to have this placed upon me? But instead of bemoaning my fate, I decided to look for the positive side of it..."

status_message:
"I was 20 weeks' pregnant when I first heard the words that took my breath away – "You have cancer." My husband and I tried for 6 years before conceiving and now I had Hodgkin's – cancer of the lymph nodes. 

We looked at each other and whispered "It'll be okay," and it was. Samantha was born at 34 weeks and I had 5 weeks of radiation to my neck and chest and was clear. 

Fifteen years flew by and when I was 45 I had my first mammogram; see, I figured I'd done the cancer thing, so why worry? It turned out that was the last mammogram I needed. Again I heard those words that took my breath away..."

Continue Reading Pam's Story ► http://po.st/XSVl7a

I was horrified to learn that I was Stage 3 and had a large tumor and 4 lymph nodes. I did everything I could: mastectomy, radiation, chemotherapy and years of tamoxifen.

I then experienced an unexpected remission of 18 years...."

status_message:
"My story......My story ten years ago I lost my brother to cancer. Two weeks later my mom was told I was most likely not going to live through the night as my bowels had ruptured and I was septic and on a respirator. 

Well I made it 6 weeks in hospital and two years to get better. I went back to school at age 45 i did it. That was 2009 I became a nurse. 

Then 2011 I found a lump in my right breast - stage 2. I wondered why back then did my brother die and not me? but I know realize it's for me to be able to give back through life experience...."

status_message:
"His small clenched hand thrust into mine and released a few small coins. I stare down at a nickel, a dime, and few pennies, "This is to help you beat cancer Mrs. Greer", he says excitedly. 

I give him a hug and a thank you with my heart so full of love, it spills out in tears. I'm greeted at the office with a child's prized piggy bank full of coins. "She wants you to have this Mrs. Greer How can I accept such sacrifice?

I am overwhelmed with emotion as I bring my treasures back to my classroom. I set the piggy bank on my shelf and the coins in a cedar box on my window sill along with a green lifesaver, a small broken candy cane, a couple of quarters, a dollar bill..."

Continue Reading Diane's Story ► http://po.st/yOVtH9

status_message:
"Hello my name is Julie and I'm a breast cancer warrior. 2 weeks before my 25th b-day I was diagnosed with breast cancer in both of my breasts. I was told that I only had 2 1/2 yrs at best. In October of 2014 I will celebrate my 10 yr survivorship mark. 

I attribute my longevity to my Lord, loved ones & friends who have supported and given me strength when I thought I had none left. I especially owe a huge amount of gratitude to my husband David. He has supported me through it all. 1 month after I was diagnosed he married me without thinking twice. 

He makes me feel beautiful everyday of my life and he is truly blind to all of the scars my body has. To date I have undergone 13+ surgeries. However..."

Continue Reading Julie's Story ►http://po.st/bnxTSu

status_message:
"I was diagnosed with breast cancer 2 weeks before my 31st birthday and 3 months after having given birth to my first and only child, Monica. This month, I celebrated 19 years since that diagnosis, and I am still grateful for every day here.

I found a lump while nursing and had it checked out. A quick, 20-minute appointment with my infant in tow turned into hours, my first and worst mammogram as a nursing mother, an ultrasound, and then a biopsy a few days later. 

They told me there was a 98% chance it was nothing..."

Continue Reading Pam's Story ► http://po.st/pv7upK

status_message:
"In 2011 at 31, instead of enjoying time with husband and 5 kids, I was bone tired. Went to doctor, nothing was found. In September I started leaking blood from right breast. 

Went back to family doc, who sent me for mammogram/ultrasound. I went over to lab for that, and was treated like an idiot. Scans showed cysts, nothing else. I asked about bleeding and heard, Youre young, come back in year for recheck. 

I was cut off, told they know what theyre doing. I called family doctor to complain, he sent me in to surgeon to see about biopsies. Surgeon refused, said wasnt necessary since the cysts were benign..."

Continue Reading Sara's Story ► http://po.st/Pieuwa

status_message:
"The first time I had it was 15 years ago and I was 44 years old. I had ductal carcinoma in situ stage 2, I had chemo 6 times and after I finished the chemo I had reconstruction on my right side. Things where going good for the 15 years. 

I would go every year for my check ups and mammograms. Well in Oct of last year (2015) I went for my yearly mammogram and they found something and advised me to see my dr. 

I had already make my yearly appt with the breast cancer dr. When I took the film to my dr. he didn't like what he say and advised me to have my left breast removed. It was cancer again, but this time it was only stage 0..."

Continue Reading Donna's Story ► http://po.st/pO78FQ

status_message:
"In July of 2015 I went for my annual mammogram as I did each year with no thought of anything unusual happening. I left that day and they called me back in for a repeat on my right breast followed by an ultrasound. 

In my mind, I didn't think twice, as this had happen before only to find I had a cyst. Not this time...they did the repeat scan and ultrasound, and said it was suspicious and sent me right to the hospital for a biopsy. 

They said they would call me the next morning with the result, and when the phone rang that following morning I heard the words that anyone would dread that it was cancer...."

"I was first diagnosed at the age of 33 in August 2008. Stage II Breast Cancer, ER Positive and BRAC1 gene so I elected a double mastectomy. 

After surgery, receiving radiation, chemotherapy and then reconstruction surgery, my hair finally started growing back. In 2010, I received a NED (No evidence of disease)! During my treatment, I was laid off went back to college and graduated.

While working my dream job, in May 2011, my right lower thigh started hurting. I thought it was my sciatica because it hurt up into my lower back. I went to chiropractor for adjustments..."

status_message:
"On August 8, 2014 I attended a baseball game. The next morning, I was lying in bed and I noticed something different, I had a lump on my left breast that wasn't there before. 

I thought it was probably nothing because I was healthy and felt great but decided to get it checked out. I thought there was no way it could be Cancer. I had just had a mammogram in June that came back clear! This was less than 2 months later. 

I went and had an ultrasound done. Finally, after the two ladies were done with the ultrasound they turned on the light and said you are showing signs of Cancer. Hearing the news, I was so shocked as no one in my family has had breast cancer..."

"My journey began on September 7, 2015 at around 4am. I was asleep and during a dream God lifted my left hand and laid it on my right breast. 

I then woke up and felt the lump. I did not have health insurance at the time so I called the Breast & Cervical Cancer Control Program (BCCCP). 

BCCCP is a program that offers FREE mammograms, breast screenings, pap smears and follow-up testing to eligible uninsured women. They scheduled me an appointment the next day..."

status_message:
"I was diagnosed in October 2015 with Ductal Carcinoma, Invasive Ductal Carcinoma and I was Triple Negative. In December 2015 I went through a double mastectomy with reconstruction. On January 15, 2016 I began my Chemo treatments. I just wanted to share that on March 18, 2016 I received my last chemo treatment. I have to say this has been life changing. You go from being numb when first diagnosed to I can make it through this even though I am exhausted and sick. It does not seem possible that on April 8, 2016 my medi port will come out and six months have gone by. Just have to thank my friends, husband, daughter and co-workers for all of there support. Thank you for letting me share my story."

Mary Ann, congrats on your last day of chemo!! Thank you for sharing your wonderful story and picture with us :) <3

status_message:
"I have been working at an Oncology clinic since May 2013,In Nov 2013 I felt a lump on my left breast, I thought I was just being paranoid so I went on without giving it a second thought. In Jan 2014 I started having some sharp pains under my left arm. 

At this time I decided to talk to one of the nurses at my clinic to see what she thought. Without hesitation she had me scheduled for my first mammogram and sonogram, also an appointment to see a breast surgeon. 

On Jan 9th of 2014 my morning started out like any other morning I went to my appointments then had to wait until the afternoon to see the doctor..."

status_message:
"In July of 2015 I went for my annual mammogram as I did each year with no thought of anything unusual happening. I left that day and they called me back in for a repeat on my right breast followed by an ultrasound. 

In my mind, I didn't think twice, as this had happen before only to find I had a cyst. Not this time...they did the repeat scan and ultrasound, and said it was suspicious and sent me right to the hospital for a biopsy. 

They said they would call me the next morning with the result, and when the phone rang that following morning I heard the words that anyone would dread that it was cancer..."

Continue Reading Sue's Story ► http://po.st/sJZdW6

status_message:
"The first time I had it was 15 years ago and I was 44 years old. I had ductal carcinoma in situ stage 2, I had chemo 6 times and after I finished the chemo I had reconstruction on my right side. Things where going good for the 15 years. 

I would go every year for my check ups and mammograms. Well in Oct of last year (2015) I went for my yearly mammogram and they found something and advised me to see my dr. 

I had already make my yearly appt with the breast cancer dr. When I took the film to my dr. he didn't like what he say and advised me to have my left breast removed. It was cancer again, but this time it was only stage 0..."

Continue Reading Donna's Story ► http://po.st/ZtQevB

status_message:
"In 2012, I was 49 years old and I was diagnosed, after a mammogram, ultrasound and biopsy, with stage 3a invasive ductal carcinoma in my left breast. Yes...men have breasts too. Over our pectoral muscle we have a certain amount of breast tissue.

I was treated with a mastectomy with lymph node dissection, 18 weeks of aggressive chemotherapy (6 rounds, a round every 3 weeks of A,C and T) , after a little time off, 25 daily rounds of generous radiation. 

I'm currently showing no evidence of disease and I am on a 10 year course of Tamoxifen..."

Continue Reading Bob's Story ► http://po.st/hD35N6

status_message:
"Atlast, last day of chemo!

Thank you for these wonderful people who helped me during my chemo days. To my doctor, who's been kind and patiently explained my situation and my options. To the pharmacist who explained every medicines that I needed to take, especially the meds for side effect and those leaflets they made so that I can understand those meds and what to expect and prepare.. To all the nurses who attended during those chemo days,for making every chemo day, comfortable & worry free. For their extra effort because I'm a foreigner and they needed to translate everything.

My journey starts last year, Aug. 2015. A few days before my 39th b-day. I've been diagnosed of HER 2+.
It's been hard for me especially that I'm far from my family. At first it's so sad that I don't know what to do. Where should I start, where to go, what to prepare.
Eventually, I managed to deal with every step, every preparation & every laboratories I needed.

I started my first chemo Sept., 4 cycles of HER+W – PTX ( herceptine + Taxol) and 4 cycles of FEC.
I'm glad that there's a modern medicine, managing the side effects,I didn't experienced any nausea nor weakness.
I stayed as a happy and positive person inspite of what I'm conquering. That I choose to fight not for myself but for my love ones, specially for my kids. That no matter what I am facing right now, I know and I believe that I can conquer it. I am stronger than Cancer, it cannot beat me. And my Faith is greater than my fear.

Thank you to my Family, relatives & friends for all their love and support.
To Yamagiwa & Sato Family for their understanding& caring.
To Mayuko-san, eventhough im not working with her anymore, she still send her support & care. To all her letters to my doctor.
To Mrs. Peris for her love & prayers.
To my Embassy who helped me with my expenses. To the Ambassador & Diplomats who's been so understanding & grateful.
To those I've met during my sessions, thanks.
To Grace who accompanied me everytime she's free.
To Tony who never left my side & gave me strength, I love you.
Lastly, Thanks to our Mighty God for giving me strength & courage to face this situation. For giving me these people who helped me emotionally, spiritually & financially. For showering me all the blessings I needed.
I'm always praying for those who are in this situation, to have the strength & proper medical attention they're need. That all patients will have a chance for affordable treatment, support they need & be cured.
I just need to recuperate from the chemo then operation is next, probably on the 2nd or 3rd week of April.
Thank you All!
God bless!!"

Ma, congrats on your last day of chemo!!! Thank you for sharing your picture with us :)
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
"I was diagnosed with Lymphoma in 2007. By the time I was diagnosed, the cancer had already started spreading, and fast. 

I had 3 tumors in my chest, a mass the size of a soccer ball underneath my left lung, and the cancer cells had made their way into my small intestines. I was at stage 4. 

I went through 9 1/2 months of intense chemo, 8 hours each time. I think the chemo was the worse. Within the first two weeks after my first treatment, my hair began to come out by the handfuls. Here I am today..."

Continue Reading Cassandra's Story ► http://po.st/q68C9M

status_message:
"During our annual physicals, the doctor found a lump that needed to be looked at. It turned out to be Stage 2B breast cancer. The doctors we have are the greatest. They work together as a team to give us the best of the best treatment. All of this is coming at a cost. Her treatment will be at least a yearlong effort between Chemo, which we can just started. Next will come Surgery to remove both breast and the Limp nod after which will come the reconstruction. Radiation and medications will be last. We caught it early and is very treatable. This is going to take a great toll on us physically, mentally and financially.

Yesterday she completed 6 1/2 months of Chemo. We are meeting with the Surgeon and Plastic Surgeon and plan on surgery mid April. 

Brenda has her weak moments, but has handled this all like the champ she is. I love her with all my heart and can't wait for this to all be a distant memory."

Steve, thank you for sharing this picture with us. Congrats to Brenda on her last day of chemo <3!!!!

status_message:
"At 42 I discovered a lump in my breast in the shower. I was advised to have a mammogram and biopsy to diagnose the status of the lump. 

I had concerns about the safety of both the mammogram and biopsy on the grounds that I didn't want to increase the risk of cancer by exposure to ionising radiation, or spread the cancer under compression, or even seeding from the biopsy.

I then discovered Thermography - no ionising radiation, no compression and it ruled out the need for biopsy...."

Continue Reading Rosa's Story ► http://po.st/BZeJX4

status_message:
"My name is Diana Roche. In August 2003, I found out just how much of a fighter I really was. I had been feeling "not myself" for months and after numerous visits to the physician, was told I was a hypochondriac and to come back when there was really something wrong. 

Luckily, shortly after being told this, I found a lump in my left breast after a shower one day.

At age 29, I was diagnosed with stage 2 breast cancer, negative for estrogen and progesterone. After a very short discussion with my husband and my parents, I decided right away that I was going to have a left mastectomy. This would be followed by chemotherapy..."

status_message:
"Last September Jimmy and I went to the Dr. for our yearly checkup. My Dr. says to Jimmy "Your wife is perfect!!!" I said "You see Jimmy even the Dr. says so. LOL! A couple of days later I felt a lump on my right breast, within a week I heard those words no one wants to hear " sorry, you have Cancer". 

I went into fighting mode, weird thing I wasn't scared. I decided to just enjoy life as if nothing was wrong because there was nothing I could do until I received a prognosis. 

So I celebrated Jimmy's B-day, our Anniversary,finally 24 days later after many tests we met with my Oncologist a day before Jimmy gets laid off, which was a blessing because I knew he wanted to be by my side through this..."

Continue Reading Zoila's Story ► http://po.st/fcp4zj

"This last year has been a very tough time for me and my family. But if it hadn't been for the love of my life Brad Wright not sure if I would have made it through it. And for her to be a hair stylist she never grew it back till mine did. She took me to every appointment. And my sister Teresa Westfall for rallying around me for moral support. status_message:
"The first time I had it was 15 years ago and I was 44 years old. I had ductal carcinoma in situ stage 2, I had chemo 6 times and after I finished the chemo I had reconstruction on my right side. Things where going good for the 15 years. 

I would go every year for my check ups and mammograms. Well in Oct of last year (2015) I went for my yearly mammogram and they found something and advised me to see my dr.

I had already make my yearly appt with the breast cancer dr. When I took the film to my dr. he didn't like what he say and advised me to have my left breast removed. It was cancer again, but this time it was only stage 0..."

Continue Reading Donna's Story ► http://po.st/UQheDI

"A little over a year ago I got the devastating news that I had breast cancer. Invasive lobular carcinoma, stage II. Wow, it shocked my world. With no family history, being fit ,exercising and eating healthy, I found myself struggling to accept this news. 

I had so many questions which doctors couldn't answer, so I did what everyone else does, Started reading on internet and bombarded myself with too much information about breast cancer. 

The initial treatment was surgery and radiation,but because of one lymph node involvement chemo was suggested as well. They say God doesn't give you more than you can handle. I guess I could handle it..."

status_message:
"In July of 2015 I went for my annual mammogram as I did each year with no thought of anything unusual happening. I left that day and they called me back in for a repeat on my right breast followed by an ultrasound. 

In my mind, I didn't think twice, as this had happen before only to find I had a cyst. Not this time...they did the repeat scan and ultrasound, and said it was suspicious and sent me right to the hospital for a biopsy. 

They said they would call me the next morning with the result, and when the phone rang that following morning I heard the words that anyone would dread that it was cancer. All I could think of was, are you sure?? I don't have any cancer history in my family at all..."

Continue Reading Sue's Story ► http://po.st/ospBeM

status_message:
"My journey began on September 7, 2015 at around 4am. I was asleep and during a dream God lifted my left hand and laid it on my right breast. I then woke up and felt the lump. 

I did not have health insurance at the time so I called the Breast & Cervical Cancer Control Program (BCCCP). BCCCP is a program that offers FREE mammograms, breast screenings, pap smears and follow-up testing to eligible uninsured women. 

They scheduled me an appointment the next day. This was the beginning of the process that also included an ultra sound, a more extensive mammogram and a biopsy..."

status_message:
"One day in April 2008, while taking a shower I found a lump in my left breast. I thought it was probably nothing because I was 29 years old, healthy and busy with my life but decided to get it checked out by my family doctor because I would soon be leaving home to prepare for a deployment with the Army National Guard and my grandmother had breast cancer. 

The doctor sent me for a mammogram (negative) and an ultra sound that revealed a mass. I was referred to a surgeon and had a biopsy a few days later. The surgeon told me the dreaded words "you have cancer." 

I was shocked! I would no longer be fighting for my country now I would be fighting for my life..."

status_message:
"Just a few weeks before I turned 52 I found a lump in my right breast in the shower on the 05-05-15..A couple of days later I saw my GP and she said she didn't think it was anything to worry about (she called it a 'slippery mouse')..But she sent me for a mammogram and ultra sound then.. after two postponed core biopsies because of my skin condition HS I finally got that done ..Then on the 16th June 2015 I got told the Big C news, I was told it was Stage 2 Invasive Ductal & Lobular 60mm...progesterone and estrogen pos and HER2 Neg.. Then I was booked in for a Lumpectomy & sentinel nodes on the 25th June ..I'm there all ready for theatre .canuela in and all...then my surgeon askes if I have a 'wire' in?..Answer no...so surgery was postponed til the 29th June so that could be done..A couple of weeks later I get told they didn't get clear margins and 2 of the nodes had traces of cancer...so I was then give the option of deciding another Lumpectomy or Mastectomy ..eventually I decided on right Mastectomy (I did ask for both but they wouldn't remove the healthy left breast)...I had my mastectomy on the 3rd August '15 and they took another 13 nodes out all of which were negative..so that was good news and clear margins on the chest wall...I started Chemo on the 11th September 4 (3 weekly) rounds of A/C followed by 12 weekly Taxol..which I finished Friday 19th Feb '16...I started my radiation yesterday on 8th March '16 for 5 weeks..I have my name down on the waiting list to see the Plastic surgeon for reconstruction...but I'm glad chemo is done and dusted and Rads has started...I'm getting there on this long journey..I love this sign my Grandkids and Daughter in Law made me for my last Chemo day!!...(with all their hand prints..including my son's too <3
"Waving Goodbye to Chemo"
Woot Yeah!!! :)"

Sandy, yes!!! Say goodbye to breast cancer!!! =D Congrats on your last day of chemo and thank you for sharing this great news and story with us <3
link_name: Timeline Photos

8 months after my father's death, I found out something on my left breast. My doctor sent me to do a biopsy I've got my results my e-mail and there was the answer I never had an idea that I'm gonna have it at the age of 23 and a half... It was invasive ductal carcinoma.

I can't explain with enough words how I felt that moment, confused, scared but most of all, how I'm gonna tell my mother and brother that maybe i'm gonna die after losing my father. I've decided not to tell...

status_message:
"I think the day we are told that we have breast cancer is probably the day that stands out to all of us. It's a day that I will always remember -- July 9, 2014. After numerous mammograms, sonograms and finally two biopsies all within a few weeks I got my diagnosis. 

I didn't think of anything other than getting myself cancer free. When I saw my surgeon for the first time she told me she wanted me to have an MRI before surgery. 

The MRI turned up that I did have cancer in my right breast and another mass in my left breast. So once again I had to have a biopsy which was done the week of my surgery. So, the morning of my surgery is when I would find out..."

Continue Reading Lynn's Story ► http://po.st/1jdpUq

On May 7th 2014 went back to the Doctor with the same area tender and sore. Was taken to the Operating room on May 20th 2014 and that was when I received the diagnosis..."

status_message:
"On February 14, 2014, I welcomed my fiancé and future stepson on their journey from England to their new home with me. The visa process took 1.5 years so we were so happy to be able to get on with our lives together as a family. I took the following week off from work so we could get settled in properly.

My six month mammogram and ultra sound was scheduled for that week also, so I would not have to take any additional time off from work. 

I was on a six month schedule because I had many complex cysts and my surgeon and I decided to watch in case anything turned cancerous. After several all clear screenings and biopsies, my luck had run out. I was diagnosed with stage 2B breast cancer..."

Continue Reading Sue's Story ► http://po.st/viYWGV

status_message:
" I never thought my life would change so drastically, when, after a surgical biopsy found a malignant tumor in my right breast in September 2013. I'll say upfront that I am single and pretty much on my own in life. 

But my dad and mother are still going strong and I couldn't have done treatment without them. The tumor was small and at first only radiation was suggested. The crux of my story is that I was born breech with the cord asphyxiating me and that accident left me with the ambiguously named condition, cerebral palsy. Medically, it is called anoxia. 

My Onca score for recurrence was very high. Chemo was set up. Because of the anoxia..."

Continue Reading ► http://po.st/tDW5uc

status_message:
"My story began on September 4, 2014 during my annual mammogram appointment. The technician was taking several more images of my left breast than normal and at that time I knew something was not right. 

The following day I received a telephone call to come back in for more images. Following more images, an ultrasound, and a needle biopsy on September 19th I did receive the call with the unwanted words, "you do have breast cancer." I was diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma. 

Being a healthy woman in her 50s who takes no medication and no breast cancer history in my immediate family it certainly came as a shock to me..."

status_message:
"After being diagnosed with breast cancer, Invasive ductal carcinoma of right breast, Stage 1 Grade 3, Triple negative, on Sept. 28th at the age of 40 I have to say yesterday was one of the best days of my life, my last Chemo! I started Chemo on Oct. 15th
Now I'll be having a lumpectomy on March 28th, then 6 weeks of Radiation to follow.
My Dr. Is Super impressed that I had no problems with chemo, 4 rounds of Cytoxan then 12 rounds of Doxorubicin, he called me "super woman"
I was not looking for the lump, I was rinsing the soap from under my arm when I found it, I called my Dr. right away and they got the ball rolling, everything happened so fast, mammogram, ultra sound and biopsy within 2 weeks, I am so thankful for having such a great support group and a loving husband who hasn't left my side"

Carol, congrats on your last day of chemo!! :) Thank you for sharing this photo with us <3

status_message:
"I was diagnosed on 12/27/12 with breast cancer. "You have cancer". Those three words changed my life and were the beginning of what has proven to be an unpredictable, incredibly difficult journey.

My initial diagnosis was Stage 1 IDC with a treatment plan of a lumpectomy, 33 rounds of radiation followed by 10 years of Tamoxifen. I was told that I was "lucky". The pathology report after the lumpectomy revealed that I was less "lucky" than was originally thought as it had spread to the lymph nodes. 

Needless to say I was shocked, scared and angry. I had just started to come to grips with the diagnosis and original treatment plan..."

Continue Reading Lori's Story ► http://po.st/tFXNb2

status_message:
"I didn't think at 33 years old I would be diagnosed with breast cancer. Away on vacation I found a lump in my right breast. When I came home I saw the Dr. and he said it was large and suspicious. 

Right away I was admitted to the breast clinic where an ultrasound was done. The decision was then made to have a biopsy. The ultrasound tech left me in the room for about 30 min by myself. 

You cant imagine what goes through your head in 30 min? I was sooo scared. What was taking them so long? Could it be that bad? When they came back ..."

"I got out of the shower & noticed my left nipple was inverted. "That's not good" I thought to myself; sternly chiding myself for not doing self-body exams. 

When I got to work, I called & made an appointment for my yearly exam. They could see me that week. As my Doctor examined my breast, he quietly said, "It looks suspicious..." 

He called a Surgeon & I drove from his parking lot to the Surgeon's parking lot. A biopsy was performed. A few days before Christmas, 2008, breast cancer was confirmed....

status_message:
"This was my summer of control, running every day, losing 20 pounds, meeting my 45th birthday with pride. My general checkup showed amazing blood work and kudos for the weight loss. Then I went for my mammogram. 

Having dense breasts, a return visit was a familiar experience. Then I was asked to wait for the radiologist. What?? It was likely a radial scar, but it would not hurt to check in with a breast care specialist.

So, my nurse navigator chose one within the amazing group, and the consult was set up. After an ultrasound, biopsy, genetic testing (which came up negative), and several sleepless nights, it was discovered that I had Stage 1 IDC..."

Continue Reading Jacqui's Story ► http://po.st/SkMttc

status_message:
"I was diagnosed in August 2015 following my routine mammogram (this time I did the 3D mammogram but don't know if that matters or not). Two suspicious areas were discovered and I was called back for more views and an ultrasound. I was then sent for a biopsy. The BRCA gene runs in my family but twice I was tested for it and it was negative both times so I felt "safer" than I should have. Hearing the words confirming it was cancer at 41 years old rocked my world but I quickly rallied with the help of friends and family and decided on my course of action. 

I'm a mom to three beautiful daughters ages 12, 10 and 7 and wife to a wonderful man so I want to be here for the next 40+ years for them. I chose to be aggressive in handling this. Following a double mastectomy, I started chemo and just finished with my last treatment which will be followed by my reconstruction surgery soon and then onto hormonal therapy for the next 10 years. 

Throughout all of this journey I have been blessed with the most amazing friends and family who have rallied to help shuttle our girls, cook us meals and arranged a cleaning service. Most of all their encouraging words and displays of love helped keep me strong and focused. You never know how strong you are until you are tested. I learned a lot about myself as I tackled this mountain and am forever grateful to those I am lucky enough to have in my life."

Melissa, congrats on your last day of chemo!!! Thank you for sharing :)

"Like the rest of the events on what makes up my interesting life, being diagnosed with Breast Cancer at 27 just made a huge impact. I was extremely nervous for the first day of treatment, but all that went away, because that same day, my mother passed away. 

The one person that I knew would be there every step of the way, had been called by our Heavenly Father. Hard to swallow this happening to me and my brother at this moment in time, but after some time, I knew that He had other plans for her and that she was doing so much better now. 

The beginning of the journey through treatment entitled anger, sadness, and a sense of being lost..."
